image.altText: Australia cricketer Josh Hazlewood celebrates a wicket.

props.synopsis: Australia's quicks rip through South Africa's top order before an unlikely candidate almost takes a World Cup hat-trick. Follow all the updates from Eden Gardens in our live blog.

title.children: Australia's pace trio rip through South Africa in Cricket World Cup semifinal

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: OUT! RABADA IS CAUGHT BY MAXWELL!

image.altText: Perth airport station

props.synopsis: WA Treasurer Rita Saffioti joins a chorus of state and territory leaders in lambasting the Commonwealth over the decision to wipe $30 billion from 50 projects in an effort to reduce inflation.

title.children: 'Deeply disappointed': WA treasurer blasts federal government over cuts to infrastructure spending

image.altText: Three men inspect the inside of a church that was torn apart in a bombing, scattering debris across the floor and walls

props.synopsis: A retired police commander sheds new light on claims that the former Sri Lankan government may have colluded with a terrorist group for political gain, resulting in the deaths of hundreds of people, including Australians, in the 2019 Easter Sunday bombings.

title.children: Police hit 'obstacles' probing claimed links between Sri Lankan intelligence and Easter Sunday terrorists, retired commander says

image.altText: Firefighting crews battle a large foiefront in bushland near Lightning Ridge.

props.synopsis: The volunteer firefighter was working near Walgett in NSW when he was struck by a fallen tree and later died in hospital.

title.children: NSW volunteer firefighter killed by fallen tree while working on Hudson Fire near Walgett

image.altText: Albanese and Dutton in a compositie image close up.

props.synopsis: The political week started with brisk assurances from the government of quiet competence, but went to custard quickly with the news that several sexual offenders had been released from immigration detention, writes Annabel Crabb and Brett Worthington.

title.children: Political players appear to be at war with their former selves

image.altText: Albanese and Dutton's heads in profile are aligned in the centre of the frame, Albanese scratching his neck.

props.synopsis: In barely a day, the government shifted from arguing it could not yet act on a sudden High Court order to release dozens of people from immigration detention, to rushing into law strict new conditions for the 84 who have been released. Here's what brought us to this point.

title.children: Strict conditions set down for detainees released by High Court order, as government strikes quick deal with Coalition

image.altText: Harry Souttar of the Socceroos celebrates scoring a goal with teammates.

props.synopsis: The Socceroos make the perfect start to their World Cup qualifying campaign by thrashing Bangladesh 7-0, with Jamie Maclaren scoring a hat-trick.

title.children: Socceroos thrash Bangladesh 7-0 in first World Cup qualifier

image.altText: Pedestrians cross a road near a construction site in central Sydney

props.synopsis: Economists are warning recent wages growth could fuel Australia's already sticky inflation — and put even more upwards pressure on interest rates, writes David Taylor.

title.children: The 'cruel reality' of Australia's recent wage growth

image.altText: Janene Thacker looks out a window.

props.synopsis: Centrepay is an online tool designed to help people on Centrelink pay for essentials like rent or bills through automatic deductions. But financial counsellors say the government service is instead being misused by some providers to exploit vulnerable Australians.

title.children: Disability pensioner charged $6,760 for renting a phone that retails for around $1,800

image.altText: A Jetstar plane

props.synopsis: Direct flights are set to start between Busselton and Sydney, meaning international tourists will no longer have to stop over in Perth to visit Western Australia's South West region.

title.children: Direct flights from Sydney to open WA's South West to potential international tourist influx

image.altText: Police members outside a Footscray building, two with 'forensic' written on their uniform

props.synopsis: Homicide detectives have charged a girl, aged 12, with the murder of a woman in Barkly Street, Footscray.

title.children: Twelve-year-old girl charged with murder of 37-year-old woman in Melbourne's inner west

image.altText: A woman with black hair sits with her arms folded at a table inside a home.

props.synopsis: Her novella, Cold Enough for Snow, has seen the Melbourne author win the Prime Minister's Literary Award for fiction, while journalist-turned-farmer Sam Vincent won the non-fiction category for his book, My Father and Other Animals.

title.children: Jessica Au's novella a 'crystalline technical feat' as it wins $80,000 national literary award

image.altText: The tails of Qantas planes showing the flying kangaroo pass each other at Sydney Airport.

props.synopsis: Theo Seremetidis was a health and safety representative working for subsidiary Qantas Ground Services when he told colleagues to stop unsafe work cleaning aircraft during the pandemic.

title.children: Qantas illegally stood down worker concerned about COVID risks early in pandemic

image.altText: a man in a suit with a microphone near him

props.synopsis: Carlton Football Club legend Ian Collins accuses the suburban Melbourne law firm behind a suspected multi-million-dollar Ponzi scheme of secretly placing fraudulent mortgages over his properties as part of a sophisticated strategy to swindle investors.

title.children: Footy club legend launches legal action over alleged $100m Ponzi scheme

image.altText: Two soldiers aim their weapons in a ruined building

props.synopsis: The IDF says it has struck the house of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh, the head of its political bureau.

title.children: IDF says it has struck the house of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh — as it happened

image.altText: A man leaving court covering his face with a wide-brimmed hat

props.synopsis: A wildlife rescue volunteer called to a Tasmanian family home to assist with an injured bird went on to sexually assault several children, who since the abuse last year have "rejected contact and affection" from their mother, a court hears — with the man escaping a prison sentence.

title.children: Wildlife rescuer who sexually abused kids after being called to help with dying bird escapes jail term

image.altText: A woman in a white hoodie holds up a running bib number..

props.synopsis: Data from the tracking system at the GB Ultras Manchester to Liverpool in April showed that Joasia Zakrzewski used a car for a 4km stretch of the race.

title.children: Long distance runner gets 12-month ban for using vehicle in ultra-marathon

image.altText: AN AFL footballer in a suit and tie is pictured on his way to a courthouse for a court appearance.

props.synopsis: Carlton recruit Elijah Hollands will not be eligible to be selected for the first two games of the AFL season after being hit with a conduct unbecoming charge.

title.children: Blues recruit Elijah Hollands given AFL ban for drug charge

image.altText: Standing in front of a large brown double door, Biden and Xi shake hands.

props.synopsis: After not speaking for more than a year, America's President Joe Biden and China's leader Xi Jinping met for marathon talks in San Francisco. These were the big moments.

title.children: Biden reminds Xi of his wife's birthday — and other key moments from their marathon meeting

image.altText: Di Sanh Sunny Duong wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: The motive behind a donation businessman Di Sanh "Sunny" Duong made to the Royal Melbourne Hospital during the COVID pandemic is scrutinised as part of a foreign interference trial.

title.children: 'Beijing will know what I'm doing': Secret recordings to feature at foreign interference trial

image.altText: A North Korean man in glasses and a black suit with a North Korean woman in a grey suit

props.synopsis: If North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un meets an untimely end, these experts say there's one clear successor.

title.children: She's Kim Jong Un's 'most trusted' adviser, and this expert says she has a 'sardonic, nasty streak'

image.altText: Pink stands on stage holding a mic stand as she glitters in a pink bodysuit and studded black leather jacket.

props.synopsis: In response to increasing censorship in the United States, pop star Pink is giving away 2,000 copies of books banned in Florida — the state that has cracked down hardest on public schools and libraries this year.

title.children: 'I read banned books!': Pink to give out 2,000 'banned' books at her Florida concerts

image.altText: Villawood Immigration Detention Centre

props.synopsis: The federal government is proposing the use of ankle bracelets and curfews to monitor 84 people released from immigration detention last week, in emergency legislation rushed into Federal Parliament.

title.children: Ankle bracelets, curfews proposed for people released from immigration detention after High Court ruling

image.altText: Puppies lay on a blanket

props.synopsis: Four newborn puppies have been returned to their distraught owner after they were allegedly stolen from a home in Cairns on Wednesday.

title.children: Police locate four puppies, one hidden under a bed, allegedly stolen by teenagers in Cairns

image.altText: People with rainbow flags dance outside a library.

props.synopsis: The Shepparton event was called off following an anti-LGBTIQA+ protest last week, but a group known as the Rainbow Community Angels saw that the show went on.

title.children: Show of support after drag queen story time cancelled amid safety fears

image.altText: Peter Dutton grins in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The day began with a clear sign the opposition leader was feeling confident: he held his first press conference in Parliament House in more than three months. It ended on a different note, writes David Speers.

title.children: The powerful message from Albanese that left some in the Coalition looking uncomfortable

image.altText: Swimmers at Bondi Beach

props.synopsis: The current El Niño phase of the Pacific Ocean is forecast to peak during the coming months as one of the strongest on record, laying the platform for unprecedented global temperatures through 2024.

title.children: El Niño is laying the foundations for unprecedented global temperatures next year

image.altText: A man wearing glasses, applying for jobs on his laptop, with a dog sitting on his lap.

props.synopsis: A rising number of people looking for work pushes unemployment up, despite the creation of 55,000 jobs last month.

title.children: As unemployment rises, Jack is finding it hard to career-switch from the Navy to the tech sector

image.altText: A picture of two burgers that appear visually similar.

props.synopsis: McDonald's loses its case against Hungry Jack's after a court finds the Big Jack burger is not "deceptively similar" to the Big Mac, following a trial in which experts were called in to examine the products.

title.children: McDonald's loses out in legal beef with Hungry Jack's

image.altText: Adrian Ashenden sits next to his wife on an armchair in their home.

props.synopsis: Optus is facing growing scrutiny after some triple-0 calls failed during its unprecedented outage.

title.children: When a cancer patient needed to call triple-0, 'the phone was totally dead'. It could be a breach of the law
